. 

McLean is primarily residential, with major commercial development concentrated in its portion of
. Despite its proximity to Washington, nature is not far away, on the Virginia side of Great Falls, and McLean is a favored address for many high-ranking government officials and diplomats.

The community encompasses the older settlements of Lewinsville and Langley, the latter name appearing in the name of the local high school and as a metonym for the CIA, after the location of its headquarters. The area is named after John Roll McLean, an owner of
and one of the chief investors in the Washington and Old Dominion Railway.
A car is advised to get into McLean, as public transportation is oriented to commuters.

, for example connects McLean with the East Falls Church Metro Station via Tysons Corner and the Rosslyn Metro Station along Route 123, but only during rush hour.

The Capital Beltway,
, cuts north-south through the western side of town; the Dulles Toll Road,
, follows its southern boundary; and the
follows the arc of the Potomac River on McLean's northeast. From Great Falls, VA-193, Georgetown Pike, is the main route into town.

Most sights in McLean are only accessible by car. The principal roads are Old Dominion Drive (VA-309) and Dolley Madison Boulevard/Chain Bridge Road (VA-123), the intersection of which is considered "downtown" McLean.

value: content=The headquarters of the most well-known intelligence agency of the United States government is in a part of McLean that is sometimes still called "Langley". Tours are given only with special arrangement to academic and civic groups, not to the public. Even attempting to drive down the road leading up to the CIA can get you in trouble. However, there is a virtual tour on the CIA's web site.
content=Closer, cheaper, and less crowded than the more famous

, the Farm features costumed interpreters who demonstrate the crafts, skills, foods, buildings, and other aspects of life in 1771 on a small farm. The farm produces a variety of traditional foods and crafts and offers programs for children and adults on traditional farming skills and environmental living.
content=Named for the small stream that tumbles over a dramatic waterfall before ending in the Potomac, Scott's Run Nature Preserve is criss-crossed by
, many of them challenging as they follow the rocky cliffs and sheer bluffs overlooking the river. A section of the
crosses through the park east to west.

content=Traditional foods and crafts are on hand at the Farm's Market Fairs, held on the third full weekend of May, July, and October. Whether it's furniture, flower, or jewelry; craft beer, mulled wine, or ginger ale; sweet biscuits, meat pies or spicy sausage, each member of the family can find something to take home.
This hole in the wall, located in downtown McLean across from the McDonald's, offers authentic Italian subs, pasta dishes, and assorted fast food-type fare at reasonable prices.

content=The one four-diamond hotel anywhere in the area. It's the Ritz; it's nice.
